definition:
An abelian number field is a number field $K$ such that $K/{\mathbb{Q}}$
is an abelian extension, i.e. $K/{\mathbb{Q}}$ is Galois and
${\operatorname{Gal}}(K/{\mathbb{Q}})$ is an abelian group.

The abelian number fields are classified by the Kronecker-Weber Theorem.

A cyclic number field is an (abelian) number field $K$ such that
$K/{\mathbb{Q}}$ is a Galois extension and
${\operatorname{Gal}}(K/{\mathbb{Q}})$ is a finite cyclic group
(therefore abelian).
